final_lessons.title: Game Clock & Quarters
final_lessons.description: Learn how time works in football games

variant.prompt_richtext: How many quarters are in a football game?
variant.explanation_richtext: A football game has 4 quarters. Each quarter is 15 minutes long, making a total of 60 minutes of game time.

variant.prompt_richtext: How long is each quarter in an NFL game?
variant.explanation_richtext: Each quarter is 15 minutes long in the NFL. College and high school games may have different quarter lengths.

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens between the 2nd and 3rd quarters?
variant.explanation_richtext: Halftime is a break between the 2nd and 3rd quarters. Teams go to their locker rooms to rest and adjust their game plans.

variant.prompt_richtext: When does the game clock stop?
options_json: When a player goes out of bounds or a pass is incomplete
variant.explanation_richtext: The clock stops when a player goes out of bounds, a pass is incomplete, there's a penalty, or a timeout is called. It keeps running on most tackles in bounds.

variant.prompt_richtext: What can teams call to stop the clock and discuss strategy?
variant.explanation_richtext: Teams can call timeouts to stop the clock and discuss plays. Each team gets 3 timeouts per half.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'two-minute warning'?
options_json: An automatic timeout when 2 minutes remain in each half
variant.explanation_richtext: The two-minute warning is an automatic timeout that occurs when 2 minutes remain in the 2nd and 4th quarters. It gives teams a chance to plan their final plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens if the score is tied at the end of the 4th quarter?
options_json: The game ends in a tie
variant.explanation_richtext: If the score is tied, the game goes to overtime. In the NFL, overtime is sudden death (first team to score wins) with some special rules.

variant.prompt_richtext: How long does the offense have to snap the ball after the previous play ends?
variant.explanation_richtext: The play clock gives the offense 40 seconds (sometimes 25) to snap the ball. If they don't snap in time, it's a delay of game penalty.

final_lessons.title: Common Penalties
final_lessons.description: Learn the most common penalties and what they mean

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens when a team commits a penalty?
variant.explanation_richtext: When a team commits a penalty, they usually lose yards. Offensive penalties move them back, defensive penalties give the offense yards.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is it called when an offensive player moves before the snap?
variant.explanation_richtext: A false start is when an offensive player (except the QB) moves before the snap. It's a 5-yard penalty and the play doesn't count.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is it called when a defensive player crosses the line of scrimmage before the snap?
variant.explanation_richtext: Offsides is when a defensive player is on the wrong side of the line of scrimmage when the ball is snapped. It's a 5-yard penalty for the defense.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is holding?
options_json: Illegally grabbing or restraining an opponent
variant.explanation_richtext: Holding is when a player illegally grabs, hooks, or tackles an opponent who doesn't have the ball. It's a 10-yard penalty.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is it called when a defender illegally prevents a receiver from catching a pass?
variant.explanation_richtext: Pass interference is when a defender makes illegal contact with a receiver trying to catch a pass. It's a major penalty that gives the offense the ball at the spot of the foul.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does it mean when a referee throws a yellow flag?
variant.explanation_richtext: A yellow flag thrown by a referee indicates a penalty. The referee will announce what the penalty is and which team committed it.

variant.prompt_richtext: What penalty occurs when the offense doesn't snap the ball before the play clock expires?
variant.explanation_richtext: Delay of game is a 5-yard penalty when the offense doesn't snap the ball in time. The play clock shows how much time they have.

variant.prompt_richtext: After a penalty, who decides whether to accept or decline it?
options_json: The team that didn't commit the penalty
variant.explanation_richtext: The team that didn't commit the penalty can choose to accept it (take the yards) or decline it (let the play stand). They choose whichever helps them more.

final_lessons.title: Kickoffs & Returns
final_lessons.description: Learn how games and halves start with kickoffs

variant.prompt_richtext: How does a football game start?
variant.explanation_richtext: The game starts with a kickoff. One team kicks the ball to the other team, who tries to catch it and run it back up the field.

variant.prompt_richtext: What determines which team kicks off first?
variant.explanation_richtext: Before the game, there's a coin toss. The team that wins can choose to kick off, receive the kickoff, or pick which end zone to defend.

variant.prompt_richtext: What should the receiving team do after catching a kickoff?
options_json: Run it back toward the opponent's end zone
variant.explanation_richtext: After catching a kickoff, the receiving team's returner runs toward the opponent's end zone to gain as many yards as possible before being tackled.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a touchback on a kickoff?
options_json: When the ball goes into the end zone and isn't returned
variant.explanation_richtext: A touchback occurs when the kickoff goes into the end zone and the returner kneels or doesn't return it. The ball is placed at the 25-yard line.

variant.prompt_richtext: When do kickoffs occur during a game?
options_json: At the start of each half and after scores
variant.explanation_richtext: Kickoffs happen at the start of each half and after every scoring play (touchdown or field goal). The scoring team kicks off to the other team.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is an onside kick?
options_json: A short kick where the kicking team tries to recover the ball
A kick that goes out of bounds
variant.explanation_richtext: An onside kick is a short, intentional kick where the kicking team tries to recover the ball themselves. It's risky but used when a team is losing and needs the ball back quickly.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does it mean when a returner waves their arm before catching a kickoff or punt?
options_json: They're signaling a fair catch - they can't be tackled
variant.explanation_richtext: A fair catch signal (waving arm) means the returner won't be tackled, but they also can't run with the ball. The play starts where they catch it.

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens if a kickoff goes out of bounds without being touched?
options_json: The kicking team gets a penalty
The receiving team gets the ball at the 40-yard line
variant.explanation_richtext: If a kickoff goes out of bounds untouched, it's a penalty. The receiving team usually gets the ball at their own 40-yard line, giving them good field position.

final_lessons.title: Fumbles & Turnovers
final_lessons.description: Learn how possession can change during a play

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a fumble?
options_json: When a player drops or loses the ball
variant.explanation_richtext: A fumble is when a player who has possession of the ball drops it or has it knocked out before being tackled. The ball is live and either team can recover it.

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens if the defense recovers a fumble?
variant.explanation_richtext: If the defense recovers a fumble, they get possession of the ball! They can even run it back for a touchdown. This is called a turnover.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a turnover?
options_json: When possession changes from one team to the other
variant.explanation_richtext: A turnover is when possession changes from one team to the other during a play. Fumbles and interceptions are the two main types of turnovers.

variant.prompt_richtext: Can a defensive player who intercepts a pass run with the ball?
options_json: No, the play is immediately over
Yes, they can run it back for a touchdown
variant.explanation_richtext: Yes! After an interception, the defensive player can run with the ball toward the opponent's end zone. If they score, it's called a 'pick-six' (6 points).

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens if a fumbled ball goes out of bounds?
options_json: The team that last touched it keeps possession
variant.explanation_richtext: If a fumble goes out of bounds, the team that last had possession before it went out keeps the ball. It's spotted where it went out of bounds.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is it called when a defensive player causes an offensive player to fumble?
variant.explanation_richtext: A forced fumble is when a defender knocks or strips the ball out of an offensive player's hands. It's a great defensive play that can lead to a turnover.

variant.prompt_richtext: If a QB drops the ball while trying to throw, is it a fumble or incomplete pass?
options_json: It depends on if his arm was moving forward
variant.explanation_richtext: If the QB's arm was moving forward when he lost the ball, it's an incomplete pass. If his arm wasn't moving forward, it's a fumble. This is called the 'tuck rule' situation.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why are turnovers important in football?
options_json: They give the other team possession and momentum
variant.explanation_richtext: Turnovers are huge because they give possession to the other team, often in good field position. They can completely change the momentum of a game!
